Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Imaging and Mechanics-based Projects on Accidental Cases of Trauma (IMPACT)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Wake Forest University (WFU) School of Medicine offers multidisciplinary biomedical engineering opportunities involving accidental trauma research that aim to prevent, mitigate, and improve the fundamental understanding of injury. Objectives of this REU program emphasize research training, education, mentorship, and focus on inspiring under-represented students to pursue biomedical research and career opportunities. Students from underrepresented groups including women, minorities, and students with minimal exposure to STEM research from community colleges or universities without undergraduate research opportunities will be recruited. The intended impact is to impart training and education on engineering research and the research process, cultivate lasting mentoring relationships, and foster an interest in research and higher education in the REU participants. Research training, education on the research process and professional development topics, and mentorship are provided to REU participants through imaging and mechanics-based projects related to the prevention, mitigation, treatment, and scientific understanding of accidental trauma. Contributions from the offered projects within this REU Site project will include development of injury prediction models, vehicle and sporting safety improvements, and advancements in osteoporosis prevention, surgical fixation of injuries, trauma resuscitation procedures, and cancer radiation therapies.

During a ten-week summer program, student activities will include hands-on research training that encourages participants to make creative contributions to research projects. Participants will receive mentoring from faculty and graduate students, and will attend a weekly Research Training Seminar Series, networking, outreach, and social events. Participants will write an abstract and give an oral presentation at an Undergraduate Summer Research Symposium. Twelve students each year will be selected based on evidence of academic achievement, high potential to benefit from the research experience, and the student's contribution to the geographic, ethnic, and gender diversity of the REU participant group. Students will gain a fundamental understanding of injury research, will develop into more independent researchers, and will be encouraged to pursue educational and career opportunities in biomedical research. Research findings will be disseminated via publications and presentations co-authored by REU participants. The REU Site program is based at Wake Forest University (WFU) Health Sciences, with locations of proposed research at WFU Innovation Quarter and WFU Baptist Health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Wake Forest University School of Medicine (WFUSM) provided research and career development opportunities for a diverse cohort of 36 REU participants within biomedical engineering. This program has been highly successful in exposing undergraduates to trauma research and generating new ideas and engineering solutions for treating and/or managing injuries. The REU was hosted on the WFUSM campus of the joint graduate Virginia Tech-Wake Forest University School of Biomedical Engineering and Sciences (VT-WFU SBES) program. It involved interdisciplinary collaborations between 12 faculty in the Biomedical Engineering, Health & Exercise Science, Orthopedics, Radiology, and Radiation Oncology Departments. Students were trained in fundamental imaging and biomechanical techniques and exposed to research cases of accidental trauma. The program engaged students in biomedical engineering trauma research, via hands-on training, complex problem solving, and scientific presentation and communication. The overarching goal was to have each participant contribute to an integral piece of a research project by gaining new research skills, allowing them to see how their research ties into the big picture of preventing, mitigating, and improving the scientific understanding of accidental traumatic injuries.

To accomplish our four goals:

1)     12 faculty mentors provided hands-on research training in biomedical engineering to the participants with an intellectual focus on the investigation of mechanistic, physiological, anatomical, and other fundamental factors related to accidental cases of traumatic injuries.

2)     Education on the research process, ethics, scientific dissemination, and societal impacts was provided through the mentored research experience, educational seminars, and student authorship of 34 conference abstracts, 68 poster/podium presentations, 4 journal articles, and a patent.

3)     Faculty and graduate students provided daily mentorship to the participants, encouraging a more independent role in the lab as they gained knowledge, built confidence, and made creative contributions to their projects.

4)     Biomedical engineering research opportunities were provided to underrepresented groups (23 women; 10 minorities) and students at colleges without undergraduate research (5 students).

The Intellectual Focus of the IMPACT REU Site was multidisciplinary engineering research in medical imaging and biomechanics to investigate mechanistic, physiological, anatomical, and other fundamental factors related to trauma. Our REU Site taught students how to use their engineering and research skills to directly impact real-world safety regulations, clinical practices, and overall quality of life for trauma victims. 

The Educational Focus imparted hands-on research, didactic, and professional development training, encouraging participants to matriculate from a dependent role to a more independent role in the lab as they gained knowledge, built confidence, and made creative contributions to their projects. Students’ knowledge was enhanced through the REU experience, as was their repertoire of laboratory, writing, communication, and career skills.

Research Projects: The REU offered 12 multidisciplinary imaging and mechanics projects each summer investigating trauma. Each project was structured to immerse participants in the research process including literature review, hypothesis formation, and testing and analyzing results to evaluate hypothesis acceptance or rejection. Mentors guided participants towards a more independent status over the summer, providing ample opportunities for participants to make important contributions to their research projects.

End-of-summer REU Symposium: On their last day, each participant gave a 10-min podium presentation on their research at our REU Symposium held at the Biotech Place Conference Center which was attended by 75 faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates.

Participant Outcomes: Over 90% of the participants said the research experience met or exceeded their expectations, and that it was much more effective than traditional, classroom-based ways of learning. 75% indicated the experience increased their desire to pursue graduate school. 81% of the participants have pursued higher education at top universities across the US, including MIT/Harvard and one received the prestigious NSF GRFP award. Two students have returned to pursue a PhD in our VT-WFU SBES graduate program. Five students (14%) are now working as engineers in the biomedical industry. This data indicates the success of the REU in fostering an interest in biomedical research and graduate education in our students.

Research Products: Each student was invited to submit an abstract to the undergraduate research session of the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting, and 26 (72%) students presented posters. Collectively, the REU students’ research efforts led to first authorship, co-authorship, and acknowledgement in 37 podium presentations, 31 poster presentations, 34 conference abstracts, 7 journal articles, and 1 patent.

Broader Impacts: The REU emphasized imaging and mechanics-based techniques applied as part of the research process, with an overarching goal to improve the prevention, mitigation, treatment, and scientific understanding of injuries. The participant’s projects had applications of benefit to society ranging from development of predictive models for injury; advancements in sports and automotive safety; and improvements to diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to prevent, mitigate, and treat injuries and associated sequelae. The REU was successful in preparing students of diverse backgrounds to continue STEM research and in disseminating results of the research to the broader community.
